Weaknesses:
-Not enough emphasis on theories
-Too much overlap of biostatatistics and AAMIE for those who have to take both
Strengths:
-Lab is helpful in learning such as how to interpret the output and how to analyze the data
Good class for learning how to interpret statistical findings, but not the best course to learn SAS

Strengths: Lab assignments were open-ended, which I found to be helpful.
Weaknesses: Lecture could have been more focused.

Honestly, I went to class about five times this semester. Since there are no exams, the motivation is kind of lost to go to class especially when I felt like I wasn't learning anything that wasn't covered in Biostat I. The labs were a little helpful in learning concepts, however since the codes are written for you, you aren't learning SAS either. Strengths: Easy Honors Limitations: Not really learning anything besides reading your SAS output.

The course overall was too easy. It was nice to have a chill class, but the course didn't really motivate us to retain anything. We just had to know how to do the lab for one week and then we didn't have to use any of it again. It wasn't necessary to attend classes either, just the weekly labs sessions. I wouldn't say the course progressed my knowledge of biostatistics.

It was too easy, we weren't motivated to learn anything other than how to complete the specific lab report for the week and then we didn't have to remember how to do anything after that. Most people stopped going to class because we didn't really need to.
The knowledge of this class is useful, however, if the instructor can teach the knowledge points more detailed, that would be better.

Labs were fairly easy. Everything you need to know is in the lab slides and textbook. Overall I feel that I didn't learn much or gain many skills in the context of stats. Wish there was a better focus on public health and that the data was used was more relevant. Would have loved to have actually learned how to uses SAS or R.

One strength of the course is it allows students to be creative in interpreting data and answering statistical questions. A weakness is that the course should be more structured so that in each lecture we walk away with more than a concept based understanding of the statistical theories.
This is the absolute worst course offered at YSPH.

I think the course could be improved by having more of an incentive to put the necessary work in to understand the concepts.  The lab reports were graded very easily and there were no exams, so it was easy for the class to become less of a priority when other courses required more time.
Joke of a class, but I know they're getting rid of Zelterman next year and restructuring it so this review probably isn't helpful.
The textbook is really helpful for working on the assignment, by saying this, meaning most of the gains from this model is from self learning of the textbook.
Course could be improved with better R resources. Otherwise, I enjoyed the personal approach to lab reports.

This class was entirely useless.  I don't think I've ever had a class, whether that be in middle school, high school, college, or grad school, that required less work or critical thought.  I learned not a single thing.  All I did was run a SAS output that was given to me and use basic skills that are required on the ACT science portion I could do in tenth grade.  After two semesters of "biostatistics," I do not know anything I didn't already know from taking high school statistics.  Actually, perhaps less since material was covered in a more confusing way.

This course had a lot of potential but needed a great deal more structure. The lectures were not particularly helpful and moved slowly, often repeating the same material without introducing new concepts. Lab assignments were a chance to apply concepts, but given that code was provided, not much was actually gained from the process of using SAS/R or even in writing the results up. I had a great experience with my TA (Kevin) but I got the impression from other students that they did not receive much feedback on their labs so they did not have a basis on which to improve. I think this class would benefit from having lecture slides instead of using the document camera for hand written notes and references to the textbook - this would provide structure that would help students know what to expect from the class and follow concepts better.

One of the most flexible courses where the student is not thinking in terms of passing exams. One can learn a lot from the slow paced, in depth lectures where the stress is on the ways learning biostatistics can be made more student friendly.

I have spent a very long time reflecting on the course and trying to give feedback that is both fair and helpful (which has required a lot of self-censorship). On the whole, I found this class extremely frustrating, not helpful, and unstructured. I consistently turned to StackOverflow to help me understand code and the underlying concepts behind each pset, because I simply was not able to glean this information from class. Professor Zelterman consistently said that the course was about biostatistics, not computing. However, trying to teach statistics without providing helpful coding information does not make sense in the present day. Additionally, understanding the coding can help students to understand the statistical concepts. 
I honestly don't think I would have gotten through this class without already having a very solid grounding in R -- I learned no additional computing concepts through the course. Additionally, as per the syllabus, 100% of the grade was meant to come through the psets. If a syllabus is set up in this way, then the lectures need to be helpful (even essential) in the completion of the psets. This was not the case. In fact, Professor Zelterman began taking lecture attendance without announcing this change -- if an official change was made to the grading scheme, this needed to be made clear via Canvas (while I want to give him the benefit of the doubt, the way he started taking attendance came across as vindictive). No student would typically email a professor about needing to miss a large lecture due to illness, but thanks to Professor Zelterman's unannounced change, such a student could have been penalizing for missing lecture for a legitimate reason. 

YSPH: You need to support and provide additional training to your instructors, because this course was unacceptable. PLEASE consider reaching out to Professor Jay Emerson, who teaches statistics at Yale College. He has found rigorous and clear ways to teach statistics, and I think the stats professors at YSPH would find talking with him extremely helpful. I really, really hate writing negative reviews (and feel quite bad doing it), but this class ultimately felt like a waste of my time and money, and I think I need to give that feedback honestly without being mean about it. I don't want anyone else going through a class like this, and I'm sure Professor Zelterman wants to relay his knowledge in clear and effective ways. Please make sure that something changes, so that these modifications can be made.

This course should not be a CDE requirement. Most of the material was already covered in AME and taught in a much better fashion. This course was very disappointing, partly because Professor Zelterman meant well and really wanted the class to learn but it was painful to attend class because there was no structure. After ~3 classes, literally 3/4 of the class stopped attending because the textbook was more useful. I did appreciate the critical thinking involved with the weekly labs.
Poor quality and overall overlap with other courses.
should not be in core
This course is more about conceptual basics of the biostatistics, it is fundamental for future work, but it didn't provide so much new knowledge comparing to the intro to biostatistics course.
The book of the class written by the professor is really good -- clear and concise. But his class is a little bit not fully arranged and lack focus. Some of the SAS codes are outdated.
Very good lectures with funny stories. Can definitely improve your writing skills in statistics summary.
Horrible Course, Learned Nothing. Mainly due to professor, this needs a complete revamp.

The course raised some interesting thoughts, but I failed to see why this is a mandatory course. The content can surely be covered in half a semester. And it might be better for students interested in doing serious analyses to take a higher-level class.
It had potential but was not very well organized

I think the course has suffered from going back and forth between being a required course for some MPH/PhD tracks one year, and then not being required the next. The goals are sometimes unclear, and it did not necessarily feel like a progression from Biostatistics 1. While learning to interpret the SAS output for various statistical tests was very valuable, I think it is equally valuable to experience writing some of the code for yourself.

It intergrades the knowledge of 505A and hand-on-hand using it in SAS.
It could be more practical in some cases.

Too lax, not enough assessments

You can learn a good amount if you are self-motivated, though
Great course overall but could've covered more stuff

Strengths- Was not difficult 
Weaknesses- Do not feel as though I grasped the concepts by just completing labs
I didn't find it helpful to take this course. There was a lack of structure in this course and I wished we learned more about how to use R.
Good for sas understanding not if youre looking for R
The lectures were not well organized, and did not facilitate learning.
learning how to use R would have been helpful

The course did not feel very structured at all, with the instructor often starting off the class by asking us what WE wanted to learn. I don't know, I'm here to learn from you! Because of this, some lectures felt very repetitive and it was hard staying motivated to attend class.
great textbook. I respect not having a final exam, but would make lab reports more difficult to motivate students to participate
Great and useful

The weekly lab assignments are most valuable parts of the course for me as I gained most from it.

The low attendance rate of the class (both for the lectures and the labs) was little annoying.

Overall, the lectures were alright on the surface. However, most students did not attend lecture at all except for the first few lectures and the last one. There was no motivation to attend lecture because there are no exams in the class and you don't really need to understand the material to complete the labs. If info from the lecture is needed you could look at the class notes (handwritten) that he posts online. However, these are hard to follow without context and it is much better to just never look at the notes and only at the text if you need help with lab assignments. Essentially, the lectures could provide some useful info but was overall useless and did not provide much more information than other classes. 

 If this is not a required course for you, don't waste your time and money. If this is a required course for you, petition to waive the requirement, or spend as little time on this class as possible and focus on more important ones that will actually increase your knowledge of SAS and statistical analysis.

Biostats II builds on concepts that Biostats I covered very well. I appreciated the fact that the course did not focus on technical aspects (such as calculating p-values or memorizing formulas), but instead emphasized critical thinking and mental analysis. I liked the incorporation of a term project that forced us to revisit one question throughout the entire semester (as it related to the various topics). It felt like a very comprehensive class on linear models, although I would've a wider range of topics (on other types of regression models, for example).

STRENGTHS
-- Lab assignments were prepared in advance and presented in the syllabus at the start of term, so students had the opportunity to plan ahead and work at a measured pace, in congruence with individual schedules.
-- Class material and computer labs balanced each other nicely.
-- Grades were based on weekly assignments rather than a heroic final exam or paper. This privileged steady, cumulative work over a last-minute rush of questionable value.

WEAKNESSES
-- Students were not engaged during class. I recommend 5-10 minutes during class for students to work through questions in small groups, before sharing with the full class. Also, incorporate methods to gauge understanding of the material during the lesson, and adjust course accordingly (if 90% of students answer a question correctly through a polling/voting/handraising system, move on to a new subject; if 30% of students answer a question correctly, the educator has not effectively conveyed the concept and must backtrack, rephrase, explain, elicit questions from students).

-The lack of homework assignments (aside from labs) meant that our knowledge and understanding was never really challenged or assessed
-I appreciated the emphasis on statistical thinking (as opposed to memorizing formulas or "plug and chug"), however it would have been nice to have a more rigorous format. I did not learn very much
A nice professor
ok

Weakness:

-Not sure how examples connect to the biostatistics theories learned
Strength: 
-Can tell he is enthusiastic about biostatistics
He is passionate about the material, but went off on a tangent a lot.
Dr. Zelterman was really nice, and his genuine enthusiasm for the subject and material shone through.
Dr. Zelterman was really nice and his genuine enthusiasm for the subject shone through.

Weakness: Actually a bunch of students are absent of the class, which has to prove that most of students consider that compared with listening to the instruction from Daniel, reading related books is pretty efficient. I hope that Daniel can teach this class much more structured and detailed, to make sure we can utilize the knowledge to solve practical problems.

Dr. Zelterman is a very kind and caring person who is willing to sit down to explain things to you one on one. In the classroom he often seemed slightly disoriented and his lectures were very piecemeal.

The professor's strength is that he readily accepts comments from students to tailor the course to their interests. Perhaps having more structured powerpoint lectures would be more effective in delivering content.

Dr. Zelterman explains concepts in a way that makes the topics easy to understand, which is not easy to do for a topic like biostatistics.  I understood the underlying foundation of concepts that I previously had just been able to parrot back.
No lesson plans, no preparation for class.

Dr. Zelterman wrote a wonderful book, and his teaching is not relatively so attractive though. please do not teach coding by writing down the codes on a paper, we won't be able to know how this code helps out statistical problems.
Intelligent and witty

I cannot make a fair assessment of Dr. Zelterman because after about one week of class I realized there was literally zero incentive to go to class so I never went again. He seemed nice from the first two days that I did go, though.

Professor Zelterman was very knowledgeable about statistics and excited to share this knowledge with students. I think his teaching could be improved by establishing a focus for each class and sticking to a more linear introduction of concepts instead of the more free form approach he took this semester. It was great to follow student interest, but I often ended up lost in what we were discussing because we went down a rabbit hole or repeated material that had already been taught.
One of the best instructors ever. Patiently answering each and every question in so much detail.

Please center future lectures around coding, using example problems. Teaching statistics without including the coding does not make sense, and is not helpful to students' professional goals. Additionally, if you choose to make attendance part of the grade (after not listing it as part of grading on the official syllabus), you need to make that clear. Please reach out to Jay Emerson, or sit in on one of his lectures, to see an example of an exceptionally well taught statistics course.

Strengths: provided real-life examples and had a genuine passion for the material and for students to learn 

Weakness: lecture needs much much much more structure
Professor Zelterman truly cares about his students learning the material so he tries to make the course as painless as possible.
No power point.
the content is somewhat repetitive, but professor is really nice
The instructor is really nice and patient, but I think he can be more efficient in explaining the contents.
Professor Zelterman is a very knowledgeable teacher with good patience and very kind to students. I like him. But his class is a little bit not fully arranged and lack focus.
Very good and warm-hearted. Always smiling to us.
I learned nothing
good teacher who likes to provide a comprehensive explanation, but he uses analogy too much sometimes and it becomes hard to focus on the topic at hand
Passionate professor
He is kind and nice.
Cared about students and knows his material well.
He was very knowledgeable and kind, and his textbook that he provided for the class was very useful.
Nice professor, but I wouldn't recommend taking a class taught by him.
Nice:)
More organization of the lectures, teaching R in class.
great lecturer!

You can tell that Dr. Z is very knowledgeable and passionate about biostatistics, but a third of the time, he was comparing himself/his class to what we'd learned from Dr. Claus in the first semester (i.e., saying "Dr. Claus probably didn't teach you this") which felt unnecessary. Again, not a super structured course, but you learn something new every time you attend.
very engaging, cares about students

He explains things clearly in an easy to understand way, humorous, and hard-working

He tried very hard to engage the students, however, somehow only a small number of students are engaged.

Poor. He was somewhat engaging in lecture but there was nothing of real substance to glean from the lectures. He often spent time telling stories. The focus of the class was always unclear. Although the syllabus mentioned a couple of extra assignments (chi square term problem) other than the labs, he never mentioned them during lectures and refused to provide a straight answer when asked about it, leaving students worried about whether or not the assignment was real.

Professor Zelterman is very upbeat and kind. He covers concepts in a manner that is easily digestible and answers all questions asked of him. Also, his book is very well-written and he often brings in current, real-world examples of the content to show us how concepts are practically applicable.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor was responsive to student questions about the material, and valued student input. 
-- The professor was warm and friendly to students, and demonstrably knowledgeable.
-- The professor went out of his way to bring real-world situations and issues into the classroom, so that we could see how the use of biostatistics plays out in understanding problems and making decisions.

WEAKNESSES
-- The professor asked questions, but they were generally rhetorical. I recommend asking a simple question, then instructing all students to vote on answers with raised hands, or instructing please raise your hand if you have an answer. Then pause and count slowly to 15 while our brains kick into gear. That would hold us accountable to engage with the material. 
-- The professor valued student participation, but did not have the classroom teaching tools to achieve that. Certain expectations, e.g. Sit toward the front of the room, put cell phones away, could have been put in place early on, and TAs enlisted to note participation.
Dr. Zelterman is nice but he did not seem very invested in the course. I found his lectures disorganized and repetitive.
Good

not a good class
useless
As of now, I'm not sure I would recommend to students also taking AAMIE because there is too much overlap and not enough theory. However, I can understand the importance of learning the theory.
This course has a very low workload. Attendance to class and lab isn't necessary to get a good grade as long as you read the book and look at lab powerpoint slides
BIS 505b is a continuation and deeper exploration of the topics initially covered in 505a.
I would, if you have a heavy courseload and need an easy Honors. But, Applied Analytics might be better to learn SAS and biostats at another level.
I would recommend the course for a student just looking to fulfill a requirement without much effort, but not to those who really hope to advance their knowledge and skills in biostatistic.
It's a great course for someone looking to fulfill an easy requirement, but not for someone who truly cares to advance their knowledge and skills in biostatistics.
For school of public health students, I think the contents of this class has a bunch of similarities with applied analytical methods in EPI, so there is no need to select both of these two classes.
Fairly easy, basic stats course. Didn't learn much, course wasn't difficult.
This was a required course.
Avoid at all costs
Again, will be different moving forward, so not really relevant.
it is good to know how biostatistics can help out public health issues. read the textbook and it really helps
If you chose to use the course lessons as guidelines for personal learning, you will have a great experience with this course.
This class was completely useless.  If you want to learn anything about biostatistics or SAS, go to a different school, honestly.  You will learn nothing in this class.
Yes, I would recommend this to anyone who feels biostatistics is not interesting or is impossible for them to learn! Prof. Zelterman broke those two myths for me too.

I would absolutely not recommend the course. Unless you are already a coding genius, you will not get anything other than frustration and sadness from the class as it currently stands. I know that sounds unnecessarily harsh, and I feel horrible for saying it, but I do stand by this assertion. While Professor Zelterman seems like a perfectly nice man and a good researcher, his teaching unfortunately leaves something to be desired.

Opt for AME if you have the choice. I do not think it is worth expending tuition on a class that could be learned strictly through the textbook. There was little to no work, which unfortunately created a lack of incentive to really delve into the material.
This course is required for CDE students but it was definitely much less work than I expected.
not recommend if have basics in SAS and stats already
I would not recommend it if you have already taken an intro course to biostatistics or you have already understood the basic conceptual knowledge of the biostatistics.
The book written by the professor is really good -- simple, concise and concentrate. A better arrangement for class would be much better.
Do not take this course

I'd recommend it to someone who just wants an easy course and learn some stats. but for people who want to do serious analyses, it's best for them to take other classes (if this class is not a requirement for them)
Statistical thinking, easy course with only weekly labs
It is a good course to deepen the knowledge from 505A, but this is not challengable enough if you want more practices about R and SAS.
I wouldn't recommend it if the student didn't know how to use SAS already and wasn't self-motivated

This class is for those who already have a good understanding on biostatistics but want to get additional practice. For those who do not have a good understanding, this may not be the class for you as you may not benefit from just completing SAS labs.
I would not recommend taking this course. I strongly recommend students to take the Applied Analytic Methods in Epi to learn how to use SAS.
